Catalytic upgrading of biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to biofuel 2,5-dimethylfuran over Beta zeolite supported non-noble Co catalyst Naimeng Chen Zhiguo Zhu * Haikuo Ma Weiping Liao Hongying Lü * Green Chemistry Centre, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Qingquan Rd. 30, Yantai, 264005, China Green Chemistry Centre College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Yantai University Qingquan Rd. 30 Yantai 264005 China Green chemistry centre, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Qingquan Rd. 30, Yantai 264005, China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Cobalt impregnated siliceous *BEA zeolite (Co/Beta-DA) was rationally designed and constructed for hydrogenolysis reaction of biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to biofuel 2,5-dimethylfuran, which demonstrated unique catalytic performances under mild conditions. Selectively converting biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) into biofuel 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) via hydrogenolysis route is one of significant transformations in the field of heterogeneous catalysis, which is generally performed over supported noble catalysts and/or under harsh conditions such as high temperature (above 423 K, even achieving 533 K) and H2 pressure (1–4 MPa). Herein, non-noble metal (i.e., Co) supported on siliceous *BEA zeolite with open channel systems (Co/Beta-DA) is innovatively proposed for this hydrogenolysis reaction based on strong metal-support interaction. The micro-environment and particle size of metallic Co species were closely related to calcination temperature during the preparation of Co/Beta-DA. The Co species existed in the form of CoOx on the zeolite surface or stabilized inside the zeolite pores as well as isolated Co sites within zeolite framework after calcination (above 723 K), which were reduced by hydrogen to corresponding metallic Co species. It was confirmed that this prepared sample with 20 wt % content of Co, calcined at 723 K, was an efficient catalyst for HMF hydrogenolysis to DMF under mild conditions (423 K, 1.5 MPa H2, 3.0 h), giving an excellent DMF productivity of 1.108 h–1. Thus, this contribution provides new insights for rationally constructing non-noble-based zeolite catalyst for the transformation of biomass into renewable liquid biofuels under mild conditions. Keywords Biofuel 2,5-Dimethylfuran Hydrogenolysis Non-noble catalyst *BEA zeolite 1 Introduction The energy crisis caused by the consumption of fossil resources like petroleum and coal is becoming more and more serious nowadays [1]. Hence, searching for a sustainable, environmentally friendly, and high-quality liquid fuels from biomass becomes increasingly important to substitute fossil fuels. The hydrogenolysis of biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) to 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) offers an opportunity for the up-gradation of biomass-based platform substrates to gain the potential transportation liquid biofuel. DMF possesses excellent physical and chemical properties among series of liquid fuels for example, excellent energy densities (30 kJ cm−3), ideal boiling point (365–367 K), water insoluble, easily blending with gasoline, and satisfying octane numbers (RON = 119). These superior properties make DMF become a promising liquid biofuel on the way of substituting petroleum-based gasoline [2–5]. However, hydrogenolysis reaction of HMF to DMF will also generate many by-products such as 5-methylfurfural (5-MF), methylfurfurylalcohol (MFA), 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF). The discovery of efficient catalysts is of paramount importance in biomass conversions [6–8]. Thus, noble metal catalyzed the hydrogenolysis of HMF have been studied widely in order to achieve high selectivity of DMF. Zu et al. proposed that Ru/Co3O4 catalyst was effective for HMF hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) to DMF, affording a high HMF conversion of 100 % and DMF selectivity of 93.4 % [9]. Wang et al. reported the conversion of HMF over Pt-Co bimetallic nanoparticles catalyst and 98 % yield of DMF was achieved with the high reaction temperature of 453 K [10]. Gao et al. tested the catalytic performance of RuCo/CoOx particles that gave 96.5 % DMF yield at 473 K for 2 h [11]. Bell et al. obtained 47 % HMF conversion and 15 % DMF yield over Pd/C catalyst with the H2 pressure as high as 6.2 MPa [12]. Nonetheless, the high cost intensively hinders the practical applications of noble metal-based catalyst. Therefore, the non-noble-based transition metals catalysts (Cu, Fe, Co, and Ni) are preferred due to their relative inexpensiveness and non-toxicity. Wang et al. proposed the HDO of HMF over NiCo/C catalyst using 1.0 MPa of H2, giving rise to 95.0 % yield of DMF at 403 K for 24 h [13]. He et al. pointed that the Co-(ZnO-ZnAl2O4) catalyst exhibited outstanding catalytic performance for HMF hydrogenolysis. The HMF conversion and DMF yield reached 100 % and 74.2 %, respectively, at 403 K with 0.7 MPa H2 for 24 h [14]. Parikh et al. reported a Cu-Co/Al2O3 catalyst, achieving the full conversion of HMF and 78 % DMF yield within 8 h [15]. Riisager et al. adopted methanol as not only reaction solvent but also hydrogen donor to proceed HMF hydrogenolysis over Cu-doped metal oxide catalyst, which demonstrated 100 % HMF conversion and 48 % DMF yield at 533 K [16]. Whereas, most of these reported catalytic systems bear one or more disadvantages as follows, requiring the assistance of multicomponent metal, poor product yield, high reaction temperature and/or H2 pressure, long-winded time for desired DMF yield, etc. Hence, developing a catalyst with simple preparation, mild reaction conditions, and high selectivity of DMF is an urgent need for the selective transformation of HMF to DMF. Cobalt was a proper promotor no matter for noble or non-noble metal catalytic system in this reaction [17], suggesting that sole Co metal likely possesses the excellent catalytic performance for the hydrodeoxygenation of HMF to DMF. The Beta zeolite with highly crystalline structure, uniform pore, highly thermal stability, and superior surface area, are widely utilized in various fields in particular catalysis [18]. Inspired by this, herein, a novel cobalt catalyst supported on siliceous Beta zeolite was developed for the HDO of HMF to biofuel DMF with tetrahydrofuran as solvent. It achieved 100 % HMF conversion and 83.1 % DMF yield at 423 K within 3 h. This result confirmed that Co-based Beta zeolite bears the potential of industrialized application for the production of renewable liquid DMF biofuel. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials The following chemicals were utilized as provided without further purification: 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF, 98 %, Shanghai Bide Pharmatech Co., Ltd), 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF, 99 %, Shanghai Energy Chemical Co., Ltd), tetrahydrofuran (THF, 99 %, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd), Al-Beta zeolite (Si/Al = ca. 12.5, Nankai University Catalyst Co., Ltd), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd), 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF, 98 %, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd), 2-methyl-5-hydroxymethylfuran (MFA, 99 %, Sigma-Aldrich Co., Ltd). 2.2 Catalyst preparation The siliceous Beta sample (Si/Al > 1900), denoted as Beta-DA, was prepared according to well-established procedures reported by our group previously [19]. In a typical synthesis, Beta-DA was added into a certain concentration of Co(NO3)2·6H2O solution with liquid-to-solid mass ratio of 30. After stirring vigorously for 6 h, this suspension was dried at 373 K overnight, calcined at different temperatures for 6 h with a heating rate of 10 K min−1. The material was designed as Co/Beta-DA-Ct, where Ct represents the calcination temperature. Then the sample was reduced using a H2 and N2 mixture gas flow (10 % volume H2, 1 bar, 35 sccm) for 2 h at 653 K, giving the final material denoted as xCo/Beta-DA-CtR (x indicates the mass content of cobalt calculated from ICP results). 2.3 Characterizations The crystal structure was identified by Rigaku Smart Lab3 X-ray diffraction (XRD) with a Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5405 Å, 30 mA, 40 kV). H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) equipped with a TCD detector under a hydrogen-nitrogen (10 % volume H2) mixture was implemented on TP-5070 adsorption apparatus to measure the reduction behavior of sample. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on a FEI Tecnai G2 f20 s-twin instrument and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out on a Zeiss Sigma 500 microscopy. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were determined on a BELSORP-MAX instrument at 77 K after activating the samples at 573 K for at least 3 h under vacuum conditions. The Si, Al, and Co contents were analyzed using inductively coupled plasma (ICP) on a Thermo IRIS Intrepid II XSP atomic emission spectrometer. UV–visible (UV–vis) diffuse reflectance spectra were performed on a TU-1901 spectrophotometer using BaSO4 as the reference in the region of 200–500 nm. FT-IR spectra were collected on a Shimadzu IRAffinity-1S FT-IR spectrometer in absorbance mode with a spectral resolution of 4 cm−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a Thermo K-Alpha equipped with a monochromatized aluminum X-ray source. The binding energies were calibrated with the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV. 2.4 HMF hydrogenolysis reaction HMF hydrogenolysis was carried out in a high-pressure autoclave (Xi’an Tai Kang Biotechnology Co., Ltd, 100 mL) with a stirring rate of 500 r min−1. Typically, HMF (0.126 g), THF (12 mL), tetradecane (0.222 g, as an internal standard), and a certain amount of catalyst were added into the sealed autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirring bar. After purging with 1 MPa H2 for five times, H2 was introduced at desired pressure and then rapidly heated to desired temperature. After reaction, the reactor was quickly cooled down in ice-bath. The liquid organics were collected by centrifugation, identified using a gas chromatography mass spectrometry (7890B-5977B), quantitatively determined by an Agilent 7890B GC (HP-5 column, 30 m, 0.32 mm, FID detector) to obtain conversion and yield. It should be noted that HMF conversion and DMF yield were determined by the following criteria. HMF conversion = 1 - moles of HMF in products initial moles of HMF × 100 % DMF yield = moles of DMF in products initial moles of HMF × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalyst Co/Beta-CtR samples were prepared by a simple impregnation method followed by calcination and subsequent reduction, as graphically illustrated in Scheme 1 . As shown in Fig. 1 , pristine siliceous Beta-DA exhibited discrete and nonuniform crystal with a diameter of 80–150 nm (Fig. 1a). After calcined at 723 K, no significant difference in size and morphology was observed for 20Co/Beta-DA-C723A sample. Followed by H2 reduction, tiny aggregations like honeycomb appeared to some extent (Fig. 1c). XRD patterns of calcined and subsequent reduced samples were executed in order to investigate the structure information of bulky phase. It could be found that the *BEA topology framework structure was well-preserved for calcined samples by comparing the XRD spectra of Beta-DA (Fig. 2 A and S1a). Additionally, the characteristic peaks at 2θ = 31.2, 36.8, and 44.8°, assigned to Co3O4 (JCPD No. 43-1003, also confirmed by XRD pattern in Fig. S1b) [9,20], were clearly observed. With the increase of calcination temperature, the peak intensities of Co3O4 seemed to enhance gradually, probably resulting from its growing crystal size [18,21]. Subsequently, these calcined materials were reduced at 653 K and the corresponding XRD patterns were shown in Fig. 2B. The peaks corresponding to the Co3O4 phase completely disappeared and the diffraction peak of HCP-Co was observed at 2θ = 44.6° (JCPD No. 05-0727) [22,23]. This result indicated that the Co3O4 phase was transformed to metallic cobalt at 653 K. At the same time, the crystal structure of Beta-DA was still intact after calcination and subsequent reduction. The FT-IR spectra of 20Co/Beta-DA samples after calcination at different temperatures were shown in Fig. 3 A. As for all the samples, the absorption peak at 661 cm−1, attributed to bridging vibration O-Co-O [24], was obviously observed, further indicating the presence of Co3O4 phase on Beta-DA. On the other hand, highly dealuminated Beta-DA-C723 zeolite (calcinated at 723 K) exhibited band at about 960 cm−1, associated with silanol defects within zeolite framework generated from the removal of Al ions in Al-Beta zeolite during acid treatment process [25–28]. It is interesting to note that the peak at 960 cm−1 gradually disappeared with the calcination temperature increasing. When the calcination temperature reached 723 K, this band nearly eliminated, implying the strong interaction between silanol defects and Co species. This also demonstrated that 20Co/Beta-DA-Ct (t ≥ 723 K) possessed some isolated Co sites in the zeolite framework. Amazing, after calcined samples were reduced in the H2 atmosphere, the silanol defects were again generated regardless of aforementioned calcination temperature (Fig. 3B). It was inferred that these isolated Co ions were excluded from zeolite framework to surface or channel. Additionally, the 661 cm−1 peak disappears completely, confirmed that the Co3O4 phase was transformed to metallic cobalt through the process of reduction, in consistent with the XRD results (Fig. 2). UV-vis spectra were also employed to give insight into the transformation of Co species during calcination and subsequent reduction (Fig. 4 ). Fig. 4A shows the UV–vis absorbance spectra of 20Co/Beta-DA at the calcination temperature varying from 623 to 923 K. All samples possessed two bands centered at about 450 and 750 nm, which are attributed to O2− to Co3+ and O2− to Co2+ charge transfer in the Co3O4 structure, respectively [21,29–31]. The peak positions for Co/Beta-DA-C623 and Co/Beta-DA-C723 were almost the same. Of particular note is that both the bands significantly shifted towards the direction of higher wavelength with the increasing of calcination temperature from 723 to 923 K. This suggested that aggregation degree of Co3O4 species became more and more severe [32], likely giving rise to the growth of Co3O4 crystal. After calcined samples were reduced, both the two bands disappeared completely and no other signals were observed in Fig. 4B, implying that Co species in Beta-DA zeolite probably existed in the form of metallic state after reduction. As can be seen from Fig. 5 , lattice fringes were clearly observed for 20Co/Beta-DA-C723R, implying the high crystallinity of Beta-DA zeolite. The majority of metallic Co on the zeolite surface appeared as particles in the size of 3–8 nm. With calcination temperature increasing from 723 to 823 K, these reduced Co metal particles seemed to sharply grow in size, even some of which achieved 30 nm (Fig. S2). These results directly confirmed the speculation in terms of metallic Co particle size from XRD depending on Scherrer equation (Fig. 2, 20Co/Beta-DA-C723R, 6 nm; 20Co/Beta-DA-C823R, 28 nm) and UV–vis (Fig. 4) analyses. The chemical state of Co species on the surface of 20Co/Beta-DA-C723 sample was analyzed by XPS. As shown in Fig. 6 , this spectrum was deconvoluted into six peaks. It possessed satellite features of 2p3/2 (approximately 787 eV) and 2p1/2 (about 804 eV), indicative of the presence of Co2+ in these samples [33]. With respect to 20Co/Beta-DA-C723 sample, binding energy values at around 783.1 and 798.7 eV, corresponding to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 of isolated tetrahedral and/or octahedral Co2+ in the zeolite framework originated from the interaction between Co2+ and silanol defects during calcination [34], were clearly observed. It also exhibited two peaks at around 781.2 and 796.9 eV, attributed to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 in CoOx species [18]. The H2-TPR profiles of 20Co/Beta-DA-Ct sample calcined at different temperature were shown in Fig. 7 . The H2 consumption peak in the region of 623–643 K was assigned to isolated Co species stabilized in the silanol defects [35]. The peaks at 523–623 and 643–673 K were associated with the reduction of Co3O4 located on the surface or inside pore of the Beta-DA zeolite to CoO and subsequent CoO to metallic Co, respectively [13,36]. The band intensity of isolated framework Co2+ for 20Co/Beta-DA-C623 was weaker in comparison with these of samples with the calcination temperature above 623 K. This may be due to that interaction between Co2+ species and silanol defects into zeolite was weak at relative low temperature, in good agreement with FT-IR results (Fig. 3A). Besides, with the temperature increasing, the reduction temperature of Co3O4 to CoO and subsequent CoO to metallic Co seemed to enhance slightly, probably resulting from the growing crystal size of Co3O4 (confirmed by UV–vis spectra in Fig. 4A and TEM in Fig. S2). It was speculated that the isolated framework Co2+ species and CoOx on the surface or stabilized inside zeolite pores were nearly capable to be reduced to metallic Co at 653 K in the flowing H2/N2 mixture. From above-mentioned characteristic results, conclusion could be made that when the calcination temperature was low to 623 K, the interaction between Co2+ and silanol defects was too weak. With the temperature enhancing, this reciprocity was strengthened to some extent but CoOx on the zeolite surface and/or stabilized inside the pores appeared to grow in size. At the temperature of 723 K, some Co2+ species intensively interacted with silanol defects, affording the formation of isolated cobalt sites within zeolite framework. The majority of these Co species was reduced to metallic cobalt with the assistance of H2 (also evidenced by Fig. S3). Thus, this Co/Beta-DA zeolite material with open channel systems should be a promising catalyst for hydrogenolysis of HMF to DMF under suitable calcination temperature. 3.2 Hydrogenolysis of HMF to DMF over Co/Beta-DA catalyst The catalytic performances of cobalt impregnated zeolites with different topology structures (MFI, three dimensional (3D) 10-membered ring (10MR); FAU, 3D 12MR; MOR, 1D 12MR; *BEA, 3D 12MR) were investigated, and the results were shown in Fig. 8 . All these samples were prepared by the similar procedure as Co/Beta-DA-C723R with Co mass contents of approximately 20 %. Firstly, blank experiment was performed without the addition of any catalysts. As expected, no product of DMF was obtained with the HMF conversion of 1.1 %. When Al-containing Beta zeolite (Al-Beta, Si/Al = ca. 12.5) was employed as support (Co/Al-Beta), the HMF conversion was significantly improved to 87.9 % but the poor DMF yield (19.3 %) was observed, possibly resulting from the negative effect of Brønsted acids sites in Al-Beta zeolite [37]. Hence, highly dealuminated or siliceous zeolites were utilized as supports to carry out this reaction in the following part. As for Co/S-1 (all-silica MFI), it shown low catalytic activity (conversion, 69.5 %; yield, 4.5 %), which may be due to the inferior diffusion properties stemmed from small zeolite channels (10MR). Employing highly dealuminated USY-DA (Si/Al = 136) and MOR-DA (Si/Al = 172) as supports, the catalytic performances (Co/USY-DA, conversion of 94.2 % and yield of 16.9 %; Co/MOR-DA, conversion of 100 % and yield of 34.9 %) were superior to Co/S-1. Nonetheless, their activities were still not ideal, in particular DMF yield, which perhaps resulted from the residual Al ions in corresponding zeolites. Very interestingly, Co/Beta-DA with almost no Al ions in zeolite support (Si/Al > 1900) and open channel systems (3D 12MR) possessed dramatically enhanced HMF conversion as high as 100 % and DMF yield of 83.1 %. Consequently, Co/Beta-DA catalyst exhibited better catalytic performance in comparison with others, which was chosen as the optimal catalyst for HMF hydrodeoxygenation to product DMF. The effect of calcination temperature during the preparation of impregnated Co/Beta-DA on catalytic performances was performed over 20Co/Beta-DA-CtR. As exhibited in Fig. 9 , the activity presented as a “volcanic type” profile with the calcination temperature increasing. At 623 K, 60.8 % conversion of HMF and 4.9 % yield of DMF could be achieved. Enhancing it to 723 K, it demonstrated maximum performances (HMF conversion, 91.4 %; DMF selectivity, 16.4 %; DMF yield, 15.0 %). With the calcination temperature further increasing, the HMF conversion and DMF selectivity gradually decrease. This experiment phenomenon could be explained by the location and crystal size of active sites (metallic Co) on the zeolite surface and/or confined within zeolite pore (see section 3.1). At 623 K, the interaction between Co2+ and silanol defects was too weak, giving rise to the less Co within zeolite pore. 20Co/Beta-DA-C623R possessed lower DMF yields. Above 723 K, the increase of particle size for metallic Co on the zeolite surface contributed to the decrease of catalytic performance. Hence, 723 K was regarded as the optimum calcination temperature to obtain maximum HMF hydrogenolysis performance. Subsequently, the cobalt loading on Beta-DA zeolite from 5 to 25 wt% was modulated under the optimal operation conditions, whose textural properties and catalytic performances were explored (Table 1 ). Obviously, the Co content on Beta-DA zeolite were approximately equal to that in the initial mixture, indicative of the high utilization efficiency of Co2+ ions. Specific surface area (SBET) and total pore volume (Vtotal) for each sample were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms as presented in Fig. S4. With Co loadings increased from 0 to 20 wt%, SBET and Vtotal slowly reduced from 644 m2 g–1 and 0.61 cm3 g–1 to 523 m2 g–1 and 0.45 cm3 g–1, respectively. Nonetheless, both SBET and Vtotal values sharply decreased for 25Co/Beta-DA-C723R sample with 24.2 wt% Co content. The catalytic performance of HMF hydrogenolysis was tightly associated with Co content as well as surface area and pore volume of zeolite support [18,38]. This HMF hydrogenolysis reaction was almost not carried out over siliceous Beta-DA (Table 1, entry 1), further confirming the active sites resulting from metallic Co species. With Co content increasing from 5 to 20 wt%, the DMF yield gradually increased from 0.3–15.1 % with the enhancement of HMF conversion from 15.4–91.4 %. It was found that the HMF conversion and DMF yield decreased significantly to 79.7 % and 10.8 %, respectively, with augmenting Co loading to 25 wt%. This experiment result was likely derived from the sharp decrease of surface area and pore volume for 25Co/Beta-DA-C723R, contributing to poor organics diffusion properties. After establishing the appropriate preparation conditions (20 wt% Co, calcined at 723 K) for Co/Beta-DA catalyst, it was necessary to further optimize the reaction conditions (H2 pressure, reaction temperature, and catalyst dosage). As exhibited in Fig. 10 A, the H2 pressure ranging from 1.0 to 2.0 MPa was tested. The increase of H2 pressure contributed to the initially rapid and then slow augment of DMF yield. When the pressure was 1.5 MPa, substrate HMF was completely transformed along with the DMF yield of 83.1 %. Increasing it to 2 MPa, the DMF yield was not significantly improved. Given economic cost and experimental safety, 1.5 MPa was considerd to be the optimal H2 pressure. When referring to reaction temperature (Fig. 10B) and catalyst dosage (Fig. 10C), they exhibited similar trends as H2 pressure for the HMF hydrogenolysis. Therefore, 423 K and 0.025 g were regarded as the optimal reaction temperature and catalyst dosage, respectively. As demonstrated Fig. 11 , the effect of reaction time on the HMF hydrogenolysis reaction was also investigated. With the time prolonged (2–5 h), the conversion of HMF remained level-off stage of 100 %. It was found that the yield of DMF was highly sensitive to the reaction time. At 2 h, the main product was DMF with the selectivity of 61 %. Simultaneously, byproducts of 5-methylfurfural (MF), 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (DHMF), and 5-methylfurfurylalcohol (MFA) were produced, giving rise to the selectivity of 5.8, 1.4, and 27.5 %, respectively. After 3 h, the DMF selectivity was increased to 83.1 % in conjunction with the rapid decrease of these byproducts in particular MFA, implying that these products were intermediate species for the formation of DMF, in good agreement with literatures reported previously [39–41]. Unfortunately, further extending the reaction time, the selectivity of desired product DMF slightly enhanced at 4 h and subsequently even decreased sharply to 60.4 % at 5 h. Notably, 1,4-butanediol (BDO) and (5-methyltetrahydrofuran-2-yl) methanol (MTHFA) began to produce at the reaction time of 5 h. It must also be mentioned that the yields for byproducts of 2,2`-furil and unidentified products (termed others in Fig. 10) were gradually aggrandized. These phenomena were due to that the long reaction time may facilitate the polymerization of products and the further hydrogenation of the furan ring, for instance, MTHFA. Consequently, in order to obtain high DMF yield from HMF hydrogenolysis, the reaction time should be preciously tailored. The reusability of 20Co/Beta-DA-C723R catalyst was required to improve in our future work (Fig. S5). On basis of our experimental data and previous reports [41–44], we speculated the plausible reaction pathway for the hydrogenolysis of HMF to DMF over Co/Beta-DA catalysts, as illustrated in Scheme 2 . Under the present reaction conditions, biomass-derived HMF was first deoxygenated to 5-MF and hydrogenated to DHMF via two parallel routes with the aid of hydrogen. Subsequently, both 5-MF and DHMF were further hydrogenated to MFA and then quickly deoxygenated into DMF during the reaction. Furthermore, MFA and DMF were capable to be further hydrogenated into MTHFA and BDO for a long reaction time. 4 Conclusions The non-noble (Co) impregnated Co/Beta-DA catalyst with open channel systems for the selective hydrogenolysis of HMF to DMF was innovatively developed. It was found that siliceous Beta-DA zeolite with *BEA topology structure was the optimal support for HMF transformation in comparison with other topology structures (FAU, MOR, and MFI). Series of characterizations were employed to shed light on the strong metal–support interactions. The micro-environment and particle size of Co species were closely related to calcination temperature during the preparation of Co/Beta-DA. When the calcination temperature was above 723 K, Co species existed in the form of isolated sites within zeolite framework as well as CoOx on the surface and/or stabilized inside the pores of Beta-DA zeolite. The majority of Co species was reduced to metallic cobalt with the assistance of H2. 20Co/Beta-DA-C723R catalyst with about 20 % mass content of metallic Co, calcined at the temperature of 723 K, possessed optimal catalytic performances. The activity experiment demonstrated that this catalyst was an efficient and robust catalyst for HMF hydrodeoxygenation to DMF at 423 K with 1.5 MPa H2 for 3 h, affording complete conversion of HMF and 83.1 % DMF yield. Thus, we believe that non-noble impregnated zeolite rationally designed and constructed bears the potential for biomass to be converted into renewable liquid fuels. Credit author statement N. coredata.dc:description: Selectively converting biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) into biofuel 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) via hydrogenolysis route is one of significant transformations in the field of heterogeneous catalysis, which is generally performed over supported noble catalysts and/or under harsh conditions such as high temperature (above 423 K, even achieving 533 K) and H2 pressure (1–4 MPa). Herein, non-noble metal (i.e., Co) supported on siliceous *BEA zeolite with open channel systems (Co/Beta-DA) is innovatively proposed for this hydrogenolysis reaction based on strong metal-support interaction. The micro-environment and particle size of metallic Co species were closely related to calcination temperature during the preparation of Co/Beta-DA. The Co species existed in the form of CoOx on the zeolite surface or stabilized inside the zeolite pores as well as isolated Co sites within zeolite framework after calcination (above 723 K), which were reduced by hydrogen to corresponding metallic Co species. It was confirmed that this prepared sample with 20 wt % content of Co, calcined at 723 K, was an efficient catalyst for HMF hydrogenolysis to DMF under mild conditions (423 K, 1.5 MPa H2, 3.0 h), giving an excellent DMF productivity of 1.108 h–1. Thus, this contribution provides new insights for rationally constructing non-noble-based zeolite catalyst for the transformation of biomass into renewable liquid biofuels under mild conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic upgrading of biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to biofuel 2,5-dimethylfuran over Beta zeolite supported non-noble Co catalyst
